docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox had their chance to move even closer to the Yankees in the American League East but were stopped by Chris Young, a 25-year-old right-hander making just his third big-league start. Young held the Red Sox to one run and two hits in five and two-thirds innings, and the Texas Rangers ended Boston's 10-game winning streak with an 8-6 victory Saturday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether or not the Mets were right in their suspicion that Mike Scott does funny things to the baseballs he pitches, they don't have to worry about the Boston pitchers scuffing the balls. The Red Sox have a good starting staff, anchored by Roger Clemens, but we've never seen them throw any pitches that are unusual. John McNamara, a good, solid manager, likes his starters and stays with them longer than some managers might. He won't go to the bullpen so quickly, trying to get to his closer, Calvin Schiraldi, with his starters. The Red Sox have a set lineup; McNamara doesn't platoon. They don't have the team speed the Mets have (their 41 stolen bases were the fewest in the American League this year and they stole only once in the playoff), but they can score runs because they do have power and they have good contact hitters. They are a predominantly right-handed-hitting ball club. They have three left-handed hitters in the lineup, but Wade Boggs hits for a high average against left-handers, Rich Gedman stays in well against them and Bill Buckner can put the bat on the ball against them. So I would say that the Red Sox would do better against left-handed starters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Enough was enough, the Boston Red Sox apparently decided yesterday at Yankee Stadium. Their 4-1 victory ended a streak of eight consecutive losses to the Yankees, and their four runs in the first two innings beat Gaylord Perry, a pitcher they had not defeated in more than three years. The loss, coupled with Baltimore's 6-1 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays last night in Baltimore, reduced the Yankees' lead to four games in the American League East. There are 14 games remaining for the Yankees and the Orioles.
